newsitem.title: ZIMBABWE: Mbeki seeks to calm investor fears about S.Africa.
newsitem.headline: Mbeki seeks to calm investor fears about S.Africa.

text.p: South African deputy president Thabo Mbeki on Thursday sought to soothe overseas investor nerves about political instability and crime in South Africa.

Mbeki said the first full democratic poll in 1994 and this year's successful provincial elections in the violence-wracked province of KwaZulu-Natal showed fears over political instability were exaggerated.

"Democratic organs (of state) are functioning well...this is what really addresses the matter of political stability in the country," he told the Southern Africa Trade and Investment Summit being held in Harare.
Mbeki, who is the designated successor to president Nelson Mandela, said South Africans as a whole were happy with the consensus built in the 2-1/2 years since the first all-race elections.
"For South Africans generally I don't think there are many fears about what might happen in the future," he said.
The summit has brought together political and business leaders from all over southern Africa in order to try and boost regional trade and woo foreign investment.
One of the main fears that has discouraged foreign firms from investing in South Africa is a violent crime wave that has gripped the nation's cities, especially Johannesburg.
Mbeki said the problem was a hangover from apartheid days and a product of a police force geared to combating opponents of apartheid and now being faced with fighting crime.
Mbeki said the criminal justice system and law enforcement agencies had to be strengthened and the relationship between the police and the community must improve.
"If we improve the performance of the police we also create the conditions for the community to gain confidence in the police," he said.

Corruption in the police had to be rooted out. "In reality the community knows the identity of the criminals, but are reluctant to report them to the police as they believe themselves that the police are involved in crime," Mbeki said.
